DOC.HEADLINE: WHITE ' S INFLUENCE SHOWS AT SNOWBOARD FINAL

TEXT.P: Shaun White was a no-show in the halfpipe at the U.S. Open Snowboarding Championships. But several riders demonstrated his influence during the men's halfpipe finals on a warm, sunny Saturday afternoon here in the Green Mountains.

Two competitors performed 1260 aerial spins, rotating three-and-a-half times. And all three riders on the podium performed double cork 1080s -- inverted aerials while spinning two-and-a-half times that only a handful of riders have mastered.
White was the first to perform variations of both maneuvers in competition earlier this season in a push toward the Olympics in Vancouver, where he won a gold medal in the halfpipe.

In the men's halfpipe final, Kazuhiro Kokubo performed three 1080s consecutively during his winning run for a score of 97.17. It was the first victory at the Open for Kokubo, a 21-year-old from Japan. In January he won a bronze medal at the Winter X Games.
"Looking back on this season, it was so good, with the best results of my career," Kokubu said through an interpreter.

Louie Vito, a member of the U.S. snowboard team at the Vancouver Games, finished in second place with a score of 96.17 on his first of three runs. Vito performed three 1080 spins, but not consecutively. On his final run, Vito finished with a flat-spin 1260, but the move was not enough to raise his score.
"This is the Olympic year," Vito said about the next generation of progressive maneuvers, including double corks. "The riding just skyrockets. You definitely want to be on the front of that charge."

Iouri Podladtchikov of Switzerland was third with a score of 96.0 during his first run, in which he landed a double McTwist 1260, an off-axis double flip while spinning three rotations. It was White's signature move, and he was the only competitor in Vancouver to land one.

In the meantime, Podladtchikov, who finished second to White at the Winter X Games in January, had learned it, too. When he won the Winter X Games Europe in Tignes, France, last week with a run that included a Double McTwist 1260, he set up an anticipated showdown with White this week.

But White withdrew from competition earlier Saturday, the second year in a row he has pulled out of the U.S. Open at the last moment. In 2009 he was unable to compete due to an ankle injury. On Saturday morning he failed to show up for the semifinals. Officials at the Open issued a statement shortly afterward: "Unfortunately, Shaun White is exhausted and not feeling well enough to compete in today's U.S. Open halfpipe event."

On Friday White said that this week had been the first time he had ridden his snowboard since the Olympic men's halfpipe finals Feb. 17. In the meantime he had been traveling the world on a media tour, and skateboarding in Los Angeles near his home in Carlsbad, Calif.

Although the United States Open signals the end of the competitive snowboard season, White had already moved on mentally to skateboarding, his summertime diversion, in which he is also a top competitor.
On Friday, White said he was having a difficult time finding the motivation to continue snowboarding, at least in the immediate future.
"It's skate time," he said, describing plans for the competitive skateboard season and new tricks, including a 1080, a maneuver that has never been landed in a skateboarding competition.
In the women's final, Kelly Clark won a record fourth halfpipe title. The 26-year-old Clark, who grew up in nearby West Dover, Vt., has been competing at the U.S. Open for more than 10 years.
"I put in a lot of work heading into Vancouver," said Clark, who won bronze at the Olympics last month, "trying to make sure my riding is where I want it to be."

On her winning run, Clark soared higher than the rest of the women's field and performed back-to-back 720 spins (two rotations) for a score of 94.17. Kaitlyn Farrington finished second with a score of 90.33, followed by Ellery Hollingsworth with an 86.33.

Like the men's halfpipe final, the women's field also lacked some star power. The defending U.S. Open halfpipe champion Torah Bright, who won the women's halfpipe gold medal in Vancouver, elected not to travel to Vermont to rest at home in Utah.
But Clark added some sizzle. Her final run, a victory lap, was reminiscent of the men's competition, when she attempted a 1080, a move no woman has landed in competition.
Clark did not make it, but the effort was appreciated.
